Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I was just finishing up the highlights on a new client when my phone buzzed with a message from the school. My heart sank as I read it—my son had been caught bullying a classmate, and the school wanted me to come in immediately. I glanced at the clock; my client, a first-time visitor, was peering into the mirror, her lips pressed tight in disappointment. She’d been so specific about the colour she wanted, and now I could see it wasn’t quite right. I could feel her expectation for me to fix it, to make her feel beautiful and heard. At the same time, I imagined my son sitting in the principal’s office, waiting for his father to show up, to guide him, to help him understand what he’d done. My hands trembled as I tried to focus on the client’s hair, but my mind was torn. Both needed me—one as a professional, the other as a parent. I stood there, scissors in hand, caught between the demands of my chair and the needs of my child, not knowing which role to answer first.
